Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Long-Range Dipolar Fields as a Tool for Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Carlos Meriles of the City University of New York -- City College and his postdoctoral and graduate research students will develop a general strategy for high-sensitivity detection of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) for use in micro-imaging and micro-spectroscopy of organic and biological materials. This will be achieved by detecting the change in nuclear polarization, via long-range dipolar interaction, of a hyper-polarized semiconductor tip as it interacts with a sample. Prof. Meriles will also develop a new course on imaging methods for graduate students and will further develop his science course for non-science undergraduates.

Due to its low sensitivity, the spatial resolution of conventional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is limited. Scanning microscopy techniques have much better spatial resolution than MRI, but these techniques do not have the superb chemical contrast achievable with MRI. Prof. Meriles' group hopes to develop a technique that combines strengths of both MRI and scanning microscopy so that scientists may ultimately be able to obtain meaningful MRI images of single biological cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I. Summary
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), well known from clinical medicine, is a powerful tool for three-dimensional screening of biological specimens and materials alike. Among the advantages are its exquisite chemical selectivity and its non-invasive nature. Despite considerable effort to push the spatial resolution of conventional MRI into the realm of high-resolution microscopy, one invariably confronts fundamental limitations, especially detection sensitivity. Our approach uses a lattice defect in crystalline diamond—the so-called “NV center” —as a probe to monitor the minute magnetic field created by neighboring atoms. The NV center behaves as a tiny, atomic-size compass whose orientation—prepared and read-out using pulses of green light—changes depending on the local magnetic field. Thus, valuable information on the composition and dynamics of an a-priori unknown sample can be obtained by exposing a NV-center-hosting diamond nanostructure to the local magnetic fields created by electrons and nuclei in a material system (see Fig. 1).
NV-based microscopy offers several critically important advantages for nanometer-scale magnetic resonance imaging: For example, bulky and costly superconducting magnets typical in traditional magnetic resonance are unnecessary. Further, NV sensing works under ambient conditions, making it compatible with studies of delicate biological samples in a physiological environment. This technique will allow researchers to image materials with nanometer resolution, and through combination with magnetic-resonance-inspired techniques, to perform chemical analysis and mesoscopic studies of diffusion dynamics. So far, our effort has led to significant advances that resulted in a total of fourteen peer-reviewed scientific publications, some of them highlighted by the specialized press. This project has also provided training to several graduate students and postdoctoral fellows and has brought into science a number of undergraduates many of which belong to groups underrepresented in the sciences. 

II. Recent research highlights
To carry out our experiments we have developed ‘in house’ a state-of-the-art system that integrates a purpose-built high-resolution optical microscope with an atomic force microscope. The former is used to optically initialize and read-out the NV center orientation while the latter allows us to simultaneously characterize and position the host diamond nanostructure. To encode sample information in the NV center signal, it is necessary to apply various sequences of microwave and radio-frequency pulses at more than one frequency. For this purpose we assembled a customized magnetic resonance system that allows us to simultaneously manipulate the alignment of the NV center as well as that of electrons and nuclei of different species present in a typical target sample. This sophisticated infrastructure lays the ground for singular experiments, which we illustrate below through two recent highlights.

·    Enhancing the NV center sensitivity to external magnetic fields. One of the difficulties when bringing the NV center close to the diamond surface is that impurities and other defects create strong, random magnetic fields at the NV site, limiting its ability to sense weaker fields created by the sample. This effect has a direct impact on the so-called 'coherence-time' of the NV, i.e., the time during which the NV alignment can be effectively controlled before the signal is irreversibly lost. Longer times are related to improved NV sensitivity implying that the understanding and control of the mechanisms underpinning decoherence is of the utmost importance for NV magnetometry.
